DOCNAME: ASSOCIAZIONE NAZIONALE REDUCI AND 275 OTHERS v. GERMANY
TEXT: The applicants are an association , ORG Reduci PERSON Liberazione ( GPE ) , registered in GPE , and CARDINAL natural persons who are all NORP nationals ( see list appended ) . Most of those individuals are members of the applicant association . Some of the applicants lodged the application in their capacity as legal successors . The applicants were represented before the ORG by Mr J. GPE , a lawyer practising in GPE .

Most of the applicants were members of the NORP armed forces during the Second World War . GPE had first been an ally of ORG , but after PERSON ’s fall the new ORG concluded a truce with the allied forces on DATE . As of CARDINAL DATE the NORP armed forces disarmed and captured NORP soldiers . The NORP army offered those captured NORP soldiers the choice of either joining the NORP armed forces or becoming prisoners of war . The latter were detained in labour camps and used as labourers in the NORP industry .
As of DATE those detainees were called “ NORP Military internees ” ( “ ORG ” ) .
On DATE GPE declared war against GPE .

Beginning in DATE the internees were transferred from war captivity ( Kriegsgefangenschaft ) to so - called “ civilian employment ” ( PERSON ) . At first , the internees were asked to sign an according declaration consenting to the change of their status . Despite pressure exercised by the NORP authorities , only few internees agreed to the transfer of their status . The Government of ORG then abstained from obtaining those declarations and transferred the internees to civilian status without any formal declaration . They were subsequently registered as civilian forced labourers . The working conditions and the detention in labour camps , however , did not change . The internees had to carry out physically hard work without receiving adequate nutrition and many of them died as a consequence .

CARDINAL of the applicants , among them Mr GPE and PERSON , were not members of the NORP armed forces . They were civilians who were deported to GPE and subjected to forced labour as an act of retaliation against the NORP civilian population .
GPE , after its foundation on CARDINAL DATE , did not establish any compensation schemes specifically for forced labourers .
Under LAW on GPE ’s ORG ) of DATE , the regulation of compensation claims was deferred until the final settlement of reparation .

GPE paid compensation to victims of the NORP regime , mostly to those who were living in GPE , GPE and other GPE , in particular pursuant to the provisions of LAW ( ORG ) , which entered into force on DATE . It provided inter alia compensation for detention in a concentration camp and damage caused to the detainees’ health . However , forced labour as such was not covered by the existing legislation .

In DATE GPE and GPE concluded an agreement pursuant to which GPE paid a lump sum to the NORP ORG , which then awarded compensation to victims of persecution by the NORP regime . ORG did not award any benefits to the former “ NORP Military Internees ” . They receive a supplement of MONEY per day to their regular old - age pension from ORG , as do all former members of the NORP armed forces who were detained as prisoners of war .
After DATE GPE furthermore paid lump sums to several ORG , which then created funds for victims of the NORP regime .

However , individual compensation for forced labour as such was still not provided by GPE . Hence many of those former forced labourers brought actions against NORP companies , in particular class action suits in GPE . Against that background the Government of GPE and ORG of GPE concluded a treaty that envisaged the creation of the foundation “ PERSON , Responsibility and Future ” ( ORG , Verantwortung und ORG ” “ the ORG ” ) which would provide individual compensation for former forced labourers .

GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , ORG on NORP Material Claims against GPE ( “ the NORP Claims Conference ” ) , legal representatives of former forced labourers and representatives of the NORP industry had participated in those negotiations . GPE had not been a party .

On DATE the “ Law on the Creation of the ORG “ Remembrance , Responsibility and Future ” ( Gesetz PERSON “ GPE , Verantwortung und FAC ” “ the LAW ” ) entered into force ( see “ Relevant domestic and international law ” below ) .

On DATE the applicant association , a former NORP Military LOC ( M ) and the CARDINALst applicant ( Mr GPE ) , who had been subjected to forced labour as a civilian , lodged a constitutional complaint against sections CARDINAL § CARDINAL , QUANTITY and QUANTITY of the Foundation Law with ORG .
On DATE applicants CARDINAL . DATE joined the constitutional complaint .

The applicant Mr GPE and M submitted that they had had claims for compensation for forced labour under NORP civil law in conjunction with international public law against GPE prior to the entry into force of LAW . Invoking a violation of their right of property ( LAW see “ Relevant domestic and international law ” below ) they complained that they lost those claims by virtue of LAW of LAW . All complainants contended that the exclusion of judicial review of the decisions by ORG ) violated their right to an effective remedy under LAW of LAW . Moreover , they held the opinion that the exclusion of former prisoners of war from the ambit of compensation under LAW was discriminatory and thus contrary to LAW of the German Basic PERSON ( prohibition of discrimination ) . Lastly , the complainants submitted that they had lost the right under LAW of the LAW to have the unlawfulness of their arrest , detention and forced labour confirmed by a judge .

On DATE ORG refused to admit the complaint . In respect of the applicant association the court held that the complaint was inadmissible since the association did not invoke a violation of its own constitutional rights , but solely a violation of the rights of its members . Regarding applicants nos . DATE , the court found that the complaint had been lodged outside the statutory time - limit of DATE since the entry into force of the Foundation Law on DATE . As far as the applicant Mr GPE and M were concerned the court held that their complaint was partly admissible , but unfounded .

In respect of LAW of the NORP Basic PERSON the court held that LAW did not apply to the arrest , the detention and the forced labour , since those events had taken place before LAW entered into force on DATE . Furthermore , referring to LAW ( “ LAW ” – see “ Relevant domestic and international law ” below ) the court found that international public law did not establish individual claims for compensation for forced labour . The court pointed out in particular that LAW did not establish an individual claim of compensation against a ORG , but created only claims of CARDINAL ORG . The court went on to say that it was not excluded that national law might establish claims of individuals that existed next to the claims of ORG . This , however , did not mean that there was a general rule according to which individuals had a right of compensation against the ORG which had violated LAW . Hence the question as to whether individuals were entitled to compensation was entirely dependant on domestic law .

Moreover , the court found that the exclusion of former prisoners of war from the scope of those eligible for benefits under LAW by LAW § CARDINAL was not discriminatory since prisoners of war could be compelled to perform labour under LAW . In this respect the court elaborated that the legislator was allowed to distinguish , when awarding compensation , between victims of general hardships caused by the war and victims of particular ideological persecution by the NORP regime , especially as the funds of the ORG were limited .

In respect of the exclusion of judicial review by the Foundation Law the court found that LAW of LAW required that actually a right existed whose alleged violation could be examined by the courts . The court concluded that the legislator was free to decide not to establish claims of an individual vis - à - vis a public law foundation and to exclude judicial review in this connection .

In its decision ORG pointed out that , according to his own submissions , PERSON GPE had not lodged a request for compensation with the ORG since he had not been detained in “ another place of confinement ” within the meaning of LAW § CARDINAL no . CARDINAL of the Foundation Law and was furthermore not in a position to demonstrate that he met the requirements as set up by the guidelines of ORG ( see “ Relevant domestic and international law ” below ) .

The applicants nos . DATE submitted that they had all lodged unsuccessful request for compensation for forced labour with the ORG . However , only the ORG and ORG applicants , PERSON and Mr della PERSON , presented decisions of the ORG to the ORG .

On DATE the ORG rejected the request lodged by the applicant PERSON holding that he did not meet the requirements for compensation under LAW in respect of forced labourers from LOC ; i.e. forced labour in a concentration camp , a ghetto or “ another place of confinement ” .
On DATE the ORG ’s appeals board rejected Mr della PERSON ’s appeal as unfounded , confirming that , as a former prisoner of war , he was excluded from benefits .

On DATE the ORG and GPE applicants , PERSON and Mr Malberto , who had been subjected to forced labour as NORP Military Internees , lodged requests for compensation with the ORG . By letter dated DATE the ORG informed the applicants that they did not fall within the scope of ORG , as determined by the ORG and ORG . By letter of DATE the ORG notified the applicants that its appeals board was bound by the decision of the ORG and ORG . Apparently , no formal decision was rendered by the ORG .

On DATE the applicants PERSON and Mr Malberto brought an action for declaration ( PERSON ) against GPE and the ORG in ORG as a pilot case . They requested the court inter alia to hold that they , as former NORP Military Internees , were entitled to benefits under LAW .

The court rejected the applicant ’s action . The court found that the action was inadmissible since there was no legal relationship ( Rechtsverhältnis ) between the applicants on the one hand and GPE and the ORG on the other hand , which is an admissibility criterion for an action for declaration . LAW did not establish individual claims vis - à - vis the ORG or ORG , but solely vis - à - vis the partner organisation . The court added that the fact that ORG exercised the legal supervision of the ORG did not create a legal relationship between the applicants and GPE . From the court ’s point of view the legal supervision was solely carried out in the public interest and not in the interest of the beneficiaries under LAW . The court held the opinion that the applicants were thus only indirectly affected by the legal supervision of ORG .
The court refused the applicants leave to appeal .
ORG rejected the ORG request for leave to appeal against the judgment of ORG confirming the lower court ’s reasoning .

On DATE the ORG applicant , Mr della Piazza , brought an action ( Verpflichtungsklage ) against GPE and the ORG in ORG . He requested the court to order ORG to instruct the ORG to recognise that he was entitled to benefits under LAW of LAW . Furthermore , he requested the court to order the ORG to recognise that he , as a former NORP Military Internee , was entitled to benefits under LAW of LAW .

On DATE the court rejected the applicant ’s action . In respect of the first motion the court held that the applicant could not derive any rights vis - à - vis ORG from the fact that the latter exercised the legal supervision of the ORG .
As regards the applicant ’s second motion the court found , as outlined above , that LAW did not establish a legal relationship between the applicants and the ORG .
The Foundation Law stipulates that the ORG should be endowed with MONEY ( MONEY ( ORG ) ) , to be provided equally by ORG and by NORP industry .

The sum of CARDINAL ORG is intended for the compensation of forced labour . The largest share of those funds ( MONEY DEM ) is reserved for applicants residing in GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE . The remaining share is destined for beneficiaries residing outside GPE , namely CARDINAL DEM for non - NORP beneficiaries and PERCENT ORG for NORP beneficiaries .

The remaining funds of MONEY DEM inter alia aim at compensating the loss of property or were granted as humanitarian aid to ORG and ORG on ORG , which finance social programmes for Holocaust survivors .
ORG exercises the legal supervision ( Rechtsaufsicht ) of the ORG .
Requests for compensation are not processed by the ORG itself , but by its regional partner organisations in several NORP countries . The competent partner organisation for GPE is the ORG in GPE .
Each partner organisation has an appeals board which reviews the organisation ’s decisions upon an applicant ’s appeal . Judicial review of the appeals boards’ decisions is not provided for by LAW .
The highest amount of compensation - for forced labour in a concentration camp - is CARDINAL DEM ( CARDINAL ORG ) .
Pursuant to LAW § CARDINAL of the Foundation Law forced labour carried out during war captivity , as a matter of principle , does not entitle to compensation . The provisions read as follows :
“ LAW : Eligible persons
( CARDINAL ) Eligible under this law are :

CARDINAL . NORP persons who were detained in a concentration camp as defined in CARDINAL LAW or in another place of confinement outside the territory of what is now GPE or a ghetto under comparable conditions and were subjected to forced labour ;

CARDINAL . NORP persons who were deported from their homeland to the territory of ORG within the borders of DATE or to a NORP occupied area , subjected to forced labour in a commercial enterprise or for public authorities there , and detained under conditions other than those mentioned in Number CARDINAL , or were subjected to conditions resembling detention or similar extremely harsh living conditions ; this rule does not apply to persons who because their forced labour was performed primarily in the territory of what is now GPE may receive payments from ORG ; ...
( CARDINAL ) Prisoner - of - War status does not entitle to benefits .... ”

In respect of the exclusion of former prisoners of war the travaux préparatoires state that according to international public law prisoners of war may be forced to perform work by the detaining state .

In DATE ORG obtained an expert opinion on the legal status of the NORP Military Internees which concluded that those had never lost their prisoner - of - war status , because ORG had not been in a position to revoke their status unilaterally . ORG shared that view and instructed the ORG that former NORP Military Internees were excluded from benefits under LAW .

In DATE the board of trustees of the ORG issued guidelines according to which NORP Military Internees were excluded from benefits unless they had been detained in a concentration camp . Those guidelines had been prepared in concert with ORG . In a letter dated DATE addressed to the ORG the ORG pointed out that the ORG and its partner organisations were bound by the ORG ’s position .

As regards civilian forced labourers from GPE , they , according to the aforementioned guidelines , are only entitled to benefits if they were subjected to forced labour in a concentration camp , a ghetto or “ another place of confinement ” as set out in the first sentence of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Foundation Law . Otherwise , from the ORG ’s point of view the former forced labourers would not meet the criterion of “ similar extremely harsh living conditions ” referred to in the second sentence of LAW § CARDINAL of LAW . According to the ORG there was a presumption that they were not housed under “ conditions resembling detention ” , which could , however , be rebutted by the former forced labourers .
All possible further claims against the NORP ORG or NORP companies going beyond the benefits provided by LAW are excluded by LAW , which reads as follows :
“ Section CARDINAL : Exclusions from Claims

( CARDINAL ) Payments from public funds , including social security , and from NORP business enterprises for injustice suffered under ORG as defined in LAW may be claimed only under the terms of this PERSON . Any further claims in connection with ORG injustices are excluded . This applies also to cases in which claims have been transferred to third persons by operation of law , transition , or a legal transaction .

( CARDINAL ) Each claimant shall provide a statement within the framework of the application procedure irrevocably renouncing , without prejudice to Sentences CARDINAL through CARDINAL , after receipt of a payment under this PERSON any further claim against the authorities for forced labour and property damage , all claims against NORP enterprises in connection with ORG injustice , and forced - labour claims against GPE or NORP enterprises . The renunciation becomes effective upon receipt of a payment under this PERSON . ... ”
Article CARDINAL

A belligerent party which violates the provisions of the said Regulations shall , if the case demands , be liable to pay compensation . It shall be responsible for all acts committed by persons forming part of its armed forces .
Article CARDINAL
Prisoners of war are in the power of the hostile Government , but not of the individuals or corps who capture them .
They must be humanely treated .
All their personal belongings , except arms , horses and military papers , remain their property .
Article CARDINAL

The ORG may utilize the labour of the prisoners of war according to their rank and aptitude , officers excepted . The tasks , however , shall not be excessive and shall have no connection with the operations of the war .
Article CARDINAL
In addition to the prohibitions provided by special ORG , it is especially forbidden -

To declare abolished , suspended , or inadmissible in a court of law the rights and actions of the nationals of the hostile party . A belligerent is likewise forbidden to compel the nationals of the hostile party to take part in the operations of war directed against their own country , even if they were in the belligerent ’s service before the commencement of the war . “
Article CARDINAL

“ The High Contracting Parties recognise that recourse to compulsory or forced labour may have grave consequences and undertake each in respect of the territories place under its sovereignty , jurisdiction , protection , suzerainty or tutelage , to take all necessary measures to prevent compulsory or forced labour from developing into conditions analogous to slavery .
It is agreed :
( CARDINAL ) Subject to the transitional provisions laid down in paragraph ( CARDINAL ) below , compulsory or forced labour may only be exacted for public purposes .

( CARDINAL ) In territories in which compulsory or forced labour for other than public purposes still survives , the High Contracting Parties shall endeavour progressively and as soon as possible to put an end to the practice . So long as such forced or compulsory labour exists , this labour shall invariable be of an exceptional character , shall always receive adequate remuneration , and shall not involve the removal of the labourers from their usual place of residence . ”
“ LAW
Prisoners of war are in the power of the hostile Power , but not of the individuals or corps who have captured them .
They must at all times be humanely treated and protected , particularly against acts of violence , insults and public curiosity .
Measures of reprisal against them are prohibited .
Article CARDINAL
Prisoners of war shall be lodged in buildings or in barracks affording all possible guarantees of hygiene and healthfulness .
DATE must be fully protected from dampness , sufficiently heated and lighted . All precautions must be taken against danger of fire .

With regard to dormitories the total surface , minimum cubic amount of air , arrangement and material of bedding - the conditions shall be the same as for the troops at base camps of the detaining Power .
LAW
Belligerents may utilize the labour of able prisoners of war , according to their rank and aptitude , officers and persons of equivalent status excepted .
However , if officers or persons of equivalent status request suitable work , it shall be secured for them so far as is possible .
Noncommissioned officers who are prisoners of war shall only be required to do supervisory work , unless they expressly request a remunerative occupation .

Belligerents shall be bound , during the whole period of captivity , to allow to prisoners of war who are victims of accidents in connection with their work the enjoyment of the benefit of the provisions applicable to labourers of the same class according to the legislation of the detaining Power . With regard to prisoners of war to whom these legal provisions might not be applied by reason of the legislation of that Power , the latter undertakes to recommend to its legislative body all proper measures equitably to indemnify the victims .
Article CARDINAL
No prisoner of war may be employed at labours for which he is physically unfit .
Article CARDINAL
It is forbidden to use prisoners of war at unhealthy or dangerous work .
Any aggravation of the conditions of labour by disciplinary measures is forbidden .
Prisoners utilized for other work shall be entitled to wages to be fixed by agreements between the belligerents . ... ”
Article CARDINAL
“ ( CARDINAL ) All persons shall be equal before the law .
Article CARDINAL
( CARDINAL ) ORG and the right of inheritance shall be guaranteed . Their content and limits shall be defined by the laws .
( CARDINAL ) ORG entails obligations . Its use shall also serve the public good .

( CARDINAL ) Expropriation shall only be permissible in the public interest . It may only be ordered by or pursuant to a law that determines the nature and extent of compensation . Such compensation shall be determined by establishing an equitable balance between the public interest and the interests of those affected . In case of dispute respecting the amount of compensation , recourse may be had to the ordinary courts .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL
Should any individual ’s rights be infringed by public authority , he may have recourse to the courts . ... ”
COMPLAINTS
The applicants complained under LAW and DATE , CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention and LAW No . CARDINAL of the Convention about the decisions rendered by the ORG , ORG , ORG and ORG .
In respect of LAW and CARDINAL of the Convention the applicants complained that they were denied the right to have the illegality of their deportation and forced labour acknowledged .

Invoking LAW the applicants submitted that they did not have access to a court for the judicial review of the decisions rendered by the ORG . In particular , the applicants complained that the ORG appeals body did not satisfy the requirements of an ” independent and impartial tribunal ” within the meaning of LAW .
Under LAW the applicants argued that they were discriminated against both as foreigners and as former NORP Military Internees .

Moreover , they held the opinion that they had had claims for compensation under domestic civil law in conjunction with international public law against GPE which had become extinct as a result of LAW of LAW . They therefore complained of a violation of LAW No . CARDINAL . The applicants based their claims in particular on LAW , LAW and LAW . Furthermore , the applicants argued that NORP Military Internees had been in fact civilian forced labourers and not prisoners of war as maintained by ORG . They contended that they had not been treated as prisoners of war by ORG and considered it contradictory that GPE held that alleged status against them to deny them compensation . Lastly , the applicants who had been subjected to forced labour as civilians complained about the refusal of their requests for compensation under LAW .
